terms.definition: A centralized web-based platform that provides access to documentation, guides, and information resources for users or customers.
Technical content that explains how to use, implement, or troubleshoot a software product or service.
The process of making software or documentation available and accessible to end users, typically by publishing it to a live environment.
A snippet of HTML or JavaScript code that allows content from one website to be displayed within another website.
Written materials that describe the functionality, architecture, and usage instructions for software applications.
HyperText Markup Language - the standard markup language used to create and structure content on web pages.
Cascading Style Sheets - a stylesheet language used to control the visual presentation and formatting of web pages.
A high-level Python web framework that enables rapid development of secure and maintainable websites and web applications.
A personalized web address that organizations use instead of default platform URLs to maintain brand consistency.
A piece of code, typically JavaScript, that performs specific functions when embedded in a web page.
A user interface that provides an overview of key information, controls, and metrics in a centralized location.
A software component that adds specific functionality to an existing application or platform.
The live environment where software or documentation is made available to actual users, as opposed to development or testing environments.
A web-based platform that serves as a gateway to access various resources, tools, and information from a single interface.
The underlying technology infrastructure and tools used to build, deploy, and maintain software applications or services.
